Package com.rb.nonbiz.types

Class UnitFraction

java.lang.Object
java.lang.Number
com.rb.nonbiz.types.RBNumeric<T>
com.rb.nonbiz.types.PreciseValue<UnitFraction>
com.rb.nonbiz.types.UnitFraction
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<UnitFraction>
public class UnitFraction
extends PreciseValue<UnitFraction>
Represents a continuous value from 0 to 1 (inclusive).

This is a misnomer, but we couldn't find a better name:

  1. General fractions can of course be less than 0 or greater than 1.
  2. A UnitFraction object can have irrational values within [ 0, 1 ], e.g. 0.5 * Math.sqrt(2), so it's not truly a fraction in the 'ratio of integers' sense.
See RationalUnitFraction for a special case that enforces that the values are rational numbers.
See Also:
Serialized Form

    • forgivingUnitFraction

      public static UnitFraction forgivingUnitFraction​(double value, Epsilon epsilon)
      For numerical reasons, we may sometimes end up needing to instantiate a unitFraction that is a tiny bit negative, or a tiny bit above 1. This lets you round those cases to 0 and 1, respectively, while still throwing if the input is significantly outside [0, 1].

    • forgivingUnitFraction

      public static UnitFraction forgivingUnitFraction​(java.math.BigDecimal value, Epsilon epsilon)
      For numerical reasons, we may sometimes end up needing to instantiate a unitFraction that is a tiny bit negative, or a tiny bit above 1. This lets you round those cases to 0 and 1, respectively, while still throwing if the input is significantly outside [0, 1].

    • unitFraction

      public static UnitFraction unitFraction​(long numerator, long denominator)
      This is a convenience to the caller; we don't actually store a numerator and denominator in a UnitFraction.

    • addForgiving

      public UnitFraction addForgiving​(UnitFraction toAdd, Epsilon epsilon)
      For numerical reasons, adding two UnitFractions may give us a result that slightly above 1. #add handles this already, but this allows us to control the epsilon of the 'forgiving-ness'.
